sections.title: SOURCES
sections.content_md: The Vedic texts are divided into two chronological groups: the **Early Vedic texts** (1500-1000 BC) and the **Later Vedic texts** (1000-500 BC). These periods correspond to the two phases of Aryan expansion in India. Vedic literature is also divided into **Shruti** (revealed to sages by God and passed on orally) and **Smriti** (composed by Rishis).

sections.title: A. LITERARY SOURCES
sections.content_md: The literary sources for the Vedic period are extensive and written in Sanskrit. The term **'Veda'** is derived from the Sanskrit word **'vid'** which means knowledge. Vedic literature includes the four Vedas, the Brahmanas, the Aranyakas, and the Upanishads.

sections.title: 1. THE VEDAS
sections.content_md: There are four Vedas: the Rig Veda, the Sama Veda, the Yajur Veda, and the Atharva Veda, along with their Samhitas.

sections.title: (i) The Rig Veda
sections.content_md: **The Rig Veda** is the oldest religious text in the world, known as 'the first testament of mankind'. It is divided into 10 **mandalas** and was composed during the Early Vedic Period. The hymns, dedicated to Gods by sages, are authentic sources of knowledge about the life of the people of that time. It also contains the famous **'Gayatri mantra'**.

sections.title: (ii) The Sama Veda
sections.content_md: **The Sama Veda**'s name is derived from 'Sama', meaning 'Sweet Song' or 'the melody'. Some of its hymns are borrowed from the Rig Veda. The hymns were meant to be sung by priests at the time of sacrifices.

sections.title: (iii) The Yajur Veda
sections.content_md: **The Yajur Veda** deals with hymns recited during the performance of **Yajnas**. Its hymns provide insight into the social and religious life of the Aryans.

sections.title: (iv) The Atharva Veda
sections.content_md: **The Atharva Veda** contains hymns dealing with magic and charm, with most taken from the Rig Veda. It also covers spirits, **gyan** (knowledge), **karma** (action), and **upasana** (invocation). Some hymns deal with medicines for treating diseases.

sections.title: THE BRAHMANAS
sections.content_md: **The Brahmanas** are prose commentaries on the Vedas. They explain the social and religious importance of rituals and the value of sacrifices. They are of great historical value, and each Veda has several Brahmanas.

sections.title: The Aranyakas
sections.content_md: **The Aranyakas** are known as 'forest books', written for the guidance of hermits and students in forests. They form the concluding part of the Brahmanas, with main themes of mysticism and philosophy.

sections.title: The Upanishads
sections.content_md: **The Upanishads** are philosophical commentaries on the Vedas, explaining doctrines like **Karma**, **Moksha**, and **Maya**. They are the basic source of Indian philosophy and form the foundation for later Vedic literature. Famous Upanishads include **Chandogya Upanishad**, **Kena Upanishad**, **Aitareya Upanishad**, and **Taittiriya Upanishad**.

sections.title: (i) The Vedangas
sections.content_md: **The Vedangas** explain how the Vedas should be chanted. The six Vedangas deal with pronunciation, grammar, etymology, metrics, rituals, and astronomy.

sections.title: (ii) The Sutras
sections.content_md:
**The Sutras** are divided into three groups:
*   **Srautasutras**: Deal with yajna and sacrifices.
*   **Grihyasutras** or **Smartasutras**: Deal with ceremonies connected with family life.
*   **Dharmasutras**: Provide rules of conduct for various classes and life stages.

sections.title: (iii) The Upavedas
sections.content_md:
**The Upavedas** are four subsidiary Vedas:
*   **Ayurveda**: Indian system of medicine.
*   **Dhanurveda**: The art of warfare.
*   **Gandharvaveda**: The art of music.
*   **Shilpaveda**: Art and architecture.

sections.title: (iv) Darshanas
sections.content_md: **Darshanas** are the six schools of Indian philosophy, known as **Shad-Darshanas**. They include Nyaya, Vaishesika, Sankhya, Yoga, Purva Mimamsa, and Uttar Mimamsa. They propagate the virtues of life and oppose external rituals.

sections.title: (v) The Dharmashastras
sections.content_md: **The Dharmashastras** are law-books comprising the Dharmasutras and Smritis with their commentaries. They outline duties for different classes of people, kings, and their officials. **Manusmriti** describes the Hindu code of law, including the Varnas (Castes) and the Ashramas.

sections.title: (vi) The Ashtadhyayi
sections.content_md: **The Ashtadhyayi** is a treatise on Sanskrit grammar by **Panini**. It provides information on word roots and their context in Vedic literature.

sections.title: The Importance of the Vedas
sections.content_md:
*   The Vedas are a storehouse of knowledge about the Vedic Age, reflecting the social, economic, political, and religious aspects of life.
*   Although religious, the Vedas are a valuable source of information on various subjects like music, medicine, history, philosophy, grammar, metrics, astronomy, art, and architecture.
*   The information in the Vedas is crucial due to the absence of other material remains from the Vedic Age.

sections.title: 2. THE EPICS
sections.content_md: The **Ramayana** and the **Mahabharata** are two important epics from this period.

sections.title: Ramayana
sections.content_md:
Originally composed in Sanskrit by **Maharishi Valmiki**. The story revolves around **Rama**, the eldest son of King Dashratha of Ayodhya, and the abduction of his wife **Sita** by the demon king **Ravana**. Rama, with his wife Sita and brother Lakshmana, is exiled for fourteen years. In exile, Ravana abducts Sita. Rama, with the help of **Sugriva** and **Hanuman**, defeats Ravana and rescues Sita. The epic details the battle and highlights duty, devotion, and brotherly love.

[Image: A scene from the Ramayana.]

sections.title: Mahabharata
sections.content_md:
Believed to be the work of sage **Vyasa**, the **Mahabharata** is written in Sanskrit. Originally called **Jaya** (collection dealing with victory), then **Bharata**, its final compilation is known as Mahabharata. The story is about the conflict between the **Kauravas** (100 sons of King Dhritarashtra) and their cousins, the **Pandavas** (5 sons of Pandu). The conflict over the kingdom of Hastinapur leads to the Mahabharata war, which lasts for 18 days. All Kauravas are killed, and **Yudhisthira**, the eldest Pandava, becomes the ruler.

The **Bhagwad Gita**, a key part of the Mahabharata, is a discourse given by **Lord Krishna** to Arjuna on the battlefield. It teaches about duty, Karma philosophy, and the immortality of the soul.

[Image: A scene from the Mahabharata. Lord Krishna gave Arjuna a discourse which is compiled in the Bhagwad Gita.]

sections.title: The Importance of the Epics
sections.content_md:
*   Serve as the main source of information on the political institutions and socio-cultural organisation of the Epic Age.
*   Provide information on Aryan kingdoms, armies, and weapons. They highlight the Kshatriya belief that death on the battlefield was a noble act.
*   Considered finest literary works of the ancient period, acclaimed for their literary and philosophical value.
*   Reveal the high ideals of Aryan family life.
*   Depict great heroes who embody high moral principles and have influenced successive generations.
*   The **Bhagwad Gita** elaborates on the Karma philosophy and the immortality of the soul.

sections.title: B. ARCHAEOLOGICAL SOURCES
sections.content_md: The available archaeological sources for the period include iron implements, tools, and remains of pottery.

sections.title: 1. Iron Artifacts
sections.content_md:
The discovery of iron marks an important stage in civilisation. In India, the Iron Age began in 1000 BC. While Rig Vedic people knew of a metal called **ayas** (copper or bronze), Later Vedic literature mentions **Shyama** or **Krishna ayas** (black metal) to denote iron. Iron was harder, cheaper, and more plentiful than copper and bronze. Its uses included:

*   **(i) Agriculture:** Iron tools helped clear dense rain forests in northern and eastern India, converting them to cultivable land. Iron plough-heads, sickles, and hoes allowed for cultivation of vast tracts of land. This led to the expansion of settlements like **Hastinapur** and **Kaushambi** and increased production of rice, wheat, and barley.
*   **(ii) Occupation:** The use of iron led to new trades with durable implements like saws, chisels, hammers, nails, and tongs. This supported occupations like weaving, spinning, carpentry, and tool-making.
*   **(iii) Defence:** Due to its durability and availability, iron was extensively used for making weapons like swords, armours, and shields.

[Image: Iron Implements]

sections.title: *ORIGIN OF THE ARYANS
sections.content_md:
The origin of the Aryans is a controversial topic. Various theories have been proposed:
*   **Natives of India:** Some historians believe Aryans were indigenous to India.
*   **Arctic Region:** **Bal Gangadhar Tilak**, based on the Rig Veda and Zend Avesta, concluded their original home was the Arctic region.
*   **Sapta Sindhu (Punjab):** Historian **A.C. Das** argued that Aryans originated in the Sapta Sindhu region and migrated outwards.
*   **Tibet:** **Swami Dayanand Saraswati** believed Tibet was the original home of the Aryans.
*   **Central Asia:** Professor **Max Mueller** proposed the Central Asian theory, which is widely accepted by many historians for the following reasons:
    1.  The land in Asia Minor was fertile and suitable for agriculture and animal domestication.
    2.  Stone inscriptions in Asia Minor show that Aryan gods like Indra and Varuna were worshipped there.
    3.  Flora and fauna mentioned in the Rig Veda are found in Asia Minor.
    4.  Asia Minor is equidistant from Europe and India.
    5.  Genetic traits (DNA) of the Steppe people of Central Asia show similarities with people in north India.

However, the issue of the origin of the Aryans is still being disputed.

sections.title: 2. Pottery
sections.content_md:
Pottery is an important source of information.
*   **Grey Ware (GW)** and **Painted Grey Ware (PGW)** found in Punjab and Haryana are associated with the Rig Vedic Aryans. Important sites include Bhagwanpura, Dadheri, Katpalan, and Nagar.
*   In the Ganga-Yamuna doab, the earliest iron objects are associated with **PGW Culture**, which corresponds to the Later Vedic period. PGW is a very fine, smooth, and even-coloured pottery made from high-quality clay, with geometric patterns painted in black. Floral and sun symbols are also found.
*   The PGW phase was followed by the **Northern Black Polished Ware (NBPW)** phase, beginning around 700 BC. This pottery was glossy and shining.

[Image: PGW Pottery]

sections.title: EARLY SETTLEMENTS
sections.content_md:
Based on rivers and mountains mentioned in the Rig Veda, it is believed Aryans entered India from Afghanistan and settled in the Kabul river valley and the Punjab. They called this north-western part of India **Sapta Sindhu**, or the land of seven rivers: Sindhu (Indus), Ravi, Beas, Satluj, Jhelum, Chenab, and Saraswati. This region, covering present-day eastern Afghanistan, Punjab, and parts of Western Uttar Pradesh, was later named **Brahmavarta** ('land of the Gods'). The region's conditions were suitable for stable agriculture, which led to the evolution of a new, settled culture.

[Image: EARLY AND LATER VEDIC CIVILISATIONS]

sections.title: SOCIAL ORGANISATION
sections.content_md:
**Early Vedic Period:**
*   The fundamental unit of society was the patriarchal family (**Kula**), headed by the oldest male member called **Grihapati** or **Kulapati**.
*   Marriages occurred after maturity. Monogamy was the norm, though chiefs sometimes practiced polygamy.
*   The social structure was organised as: **Grama** (village) -> **Visha** -> **Jana** (tribe).
*   The head of the village was **Gramini**, of the Visha was **Vishapati**, and of the Jana was the **Rajan** (king).
*   The king governed with help from ministers like the **Purohita** (priest) and the **Senani** (army commander). The king did not maintain a regular army.
*   The king was advised by three popular assemblies: the **Sabha** (council of elders), the **Samiti** (assembly of the people), and the **Vidatha** (the earliest assembly where women participated).

**Later Vedic Period:**
*   Kingship became hereditary and divine powers were associated with the king.
*   A system of taxation and administrative machinery began to form.
*   Popular assemblies lost their importance and came to be dominated by chiefs and nobles. Women were no longer permitted to attend.

sections.title: CLASS DIVISIONS
sections.content_md:
**Early Vedic Period:**
*   The caste system is not mentioned in the Rig Veda, but a form of class division existed. The early Aryans called the local inhabitants **Dasyus** and did not mix with them.
*   The tribal society was divided into three groups: warriors, priests, and the common people. The fourth division, the **Shudras**, is mentioned for the first time in the Tenth Mandala of the Rig Veda, which is considered a later addition.
*   Society was divided based on profession, and individuals could choose their profession. An excerpt from the Rig Veda states: *"I am a poet, my father is a physician and my mother grinds corn on stone. Being of the same family, we are engaged in different professions."*

**Later Vedic Period:**
*   Professions became hereditary, leading to the emergence of the caste system.
*   Society was divided into four distinct castes or **Varnas**: **Brahmins** (priests), **Kshatriyas** (warriors), **Vaishyas** (traders, farmers, artisans), and **Shudras** (labourers who served the other three classes).
*   The caste system became rigid. Brahmins and Kshatriyas enjoyed many privileges.
*   The three higher varnas were entitled to **upanayana** (investiture with the sacred thread). Inter-caste marriage was not prevalent.

[Image: The Varnas]

sections.title: POSITION OF WOMEN
sections.content_md:
**During the Rig Vedic Period:**
*   Women were respected and the institution of marriage was sacred.
*   Daughters had the freedom to choose their husbands.
*   Remarriage of widows was prevalent.
*   There was no child-marriage; the marriageable age seems to have been 16 to 17 years.

**In the Later Vedic Period:**
*   There was a significant decline in the status of women.
*   Their participation in Yajnas was not considered necessary.
*   They did not enjoy the right to property.
*   The freedom to choose their husbands was curtailed.

sections.title: THE FOUR ASHRAMAS
sections.content_md:
In the Later Vedic Period, the lifespan of an Aryan was divided into four stages or **ashramas**, each lasting 25 years.
1.  **Brahmacharya** (up to age 25): The student stage, where a pupil acquired knowledge in a **gurukul** and observed strict discipline.
2.  **Grihastha** (age 25 to 50): The householder stage, where a man was expected to marry, raise a family, and maintain it.
3.  **Vanaprastha** (age 50 to 75): The stage of retirement from worldly life to acquire spiritual and philosophical knowledge.
4.  **Sanyasa** (age 75 to 100): The period of renunciation, where a man would leave everything to meditate and attain **moksha** (salvation).

[Image: The Four Ashramas]

sections.title: EDUCATION
sections.content_md:
Education was imparted in **gurukuls**, the residence of the guru, which were often located in forests or on the outskirts of cities. Students lived with the guru and were treated like his own children. The student's duties included household chores for the teacher. Most teaching was done orally. At the completion of education, the student gave **guru dakshina** (a gift) to the teacher. The main objective was the physical, mental, and spiritual development of the pupils. Subjects included the Vedas, Puranas, Grammar, Mathematics, Ethics, Logic, and Military Science. Two gifted women teachers of the period were **Maitreyi** and **Gargi**.

[Image: The Gurukul]

sections.title: FOOD, DRESS AND AMUSEMENTS
sections.content_md:
**Food:**
*   The main cereal in the Rig Vedic period was barley (*yava*). In Later Vedic times, rice (*vrihi*) became common.
*   Cows were domesticated, and milk and milk products like curd, butter, and ghee were used.
*   **Soma**, an intoxicating drink, was consumed during festivals and religious ceremonies.

**Dress:**
*   Clothes were simple, consisting of an undergarment (**Nivi** or **dhoti**), an upper piece (**Vasa** or shirt), and an overgarment (**Adhivasa**).
*   Men wore turbans. Animal skins, like deer skin (**Mrigchal**), were worn by hermits.

**Ornaments:**
*   Worn by both men and women, made of gold, silver, ivory, and precious stones. Common items included earrings, rings, anklets, bracelets, and necklaces.

**Amusements:**
*   Main forms of amusement were chariot-races, horse-races, dancing, singing, and hunting.
*   Musical instruments included the drum, flute, mridang, and lute.
*   People also participated in competitive sports, festivals, and gambling.

[Image: Amusement â€” Chariot-racing]

sections.title: RELIGIOUS BELIEFS
sections.content_md:
**Early Vedic Period:**
*   People worshipped forces of nature, which they personified as gods and goddesses.
*   **Indra** was the most important god (the Rain God), also known as **Purandara** (breaker of forts).
*   **Agni** (the Fire God) was second in importance, seen as an intermediary between gods and men.
*   **Varuna** (the God of water) was the third, considered the upholder of the cosmic order.
*   Other gods included **Vayu** (wind), **Surya** (sun), and **Yama** (lord of the dead).
*   Important goddesses included **Usha** (dawn), **Prithvi** (earth), and **Aditi** (great mother of gods).
*   Gods were worshipped through **yajnas** or sacrifices.

**Later Vedic Period:**
*   Religious beliefs grew more complex. Simplicity of nature worship was lost.
*   **Prajapati** (the creator, Brahma) became the supreme god.
*   **Vishnu** came to be regarded as the preserver and **Shiva** as the destroyer.
*   Indra and Agni lost their earlier importance.
*   Rituals and sacrifices (*yajnas*) became more frequent, elaborate, and a daily routine. **Dakshina** (gifts to priests) became an important ritual.
*   The Brahmins introduced new doctrines like **karma** (action), **dharma** (duty), **moksha** (salvation), and belief in rebirth. They also emphasized penance (**tapasya**). These innovations strengthened the position and power of the Brahmins.

[Image: Brahma]
[Image: Vishnu]
[Image: Shiva]

sections.title: ECONOMY
sections.content_md:
**Early Vedic Economy:**
*   The economy was primarily **pastoral**.
*   Cattle was synonymous with wealth. A wealthy person was called a **gomat**. **Godhuli** was a term for a measure of time, **gavyuti** for distance, and a daughter was called **duhitr** (one who milks the cows).
*   Agriculture was a secondary occupation. The only grain mentioned is barley (*yava*).

**Later Vedic Economy:**
*   There was a major shift towards an **agrarian economy**. Agriculture became the chief occupation.
*   This was enabled by the use of iron tools to clear the fertile alluvial lands of the Ganga-Yamuna doab.
*   **Rice** (*vrihi*, *Tandula*, *Sali*) was introduced and became a staple food. Oxen were used to pull ploughs.
*   **Crafts:** Various craftsmen are mentioned, such as leather workers (*charmakaras*), wheelwrights (*rathakaras*), blacksmiths, potters (*kulala*), and carpenters (*taksan*). Weaving was a domestic craft.
*   **Trade:** Agricultural surplus led to the growth of trade, markets, towns, and cities. While coins had been introduced, the **barter system** was still dominant.
*   **Other Occupations:** Besides agriculture and trade, other occupations included animal domestication, metal crafts, carpentry, pottery, and fishing. Women were engaged in spinning, weaving, knitting, and dyeing.
